Hello,

EDIT: As I consider my questions were too vague, I made a reply asking for specific things after understanding a bit better how everything works with lua.

I‚Äôm learning Lua with Urho3D and right now I‚Äôm trying to bind my custom component‚Äôs API to the Lua script subsystem.

I‚Äôm reading through tolua++'s documentation and I get how it works: You provide it ‚Äúcleaned up‚Äù header files it can parse and then generate auto binding code. But the problem is that I don‚Äôt know exactly how does Urho register its API.

My question is, How would I go into registering my own API with pkg files, and adapt my build system so the bindings are generated, just like Urho does?

My main concern is how should I go with including the Urho3D headers so tolua++ can use Urho‚Äôs types. For example if I‚Äôm using RigidBody in my component, does the pkg file need that reference? Or that‚Äôs just for my own defined classes (as Urho types are already bound by the engine).

Thank you!

With some help from the IRC, I‚Äôve been able to understand a bit more how tolua++ works and when it‚Äôs called by Urho. Now I‚Äôm able to ask more specific questions.

-  If I understood correctly, each call to tolua++ generates a C file with a function that receives a pointer to the lua "context" (actually called lua_state). That function adds everything that needs to be added to the Lua state. Am I right?

- In order to actually do the binding, I should get the lua_state pointer (from the LuaScript class) and call the C generated function with it. To do so I can load the C generated function as an extern symbol into my game code, right?

- Given Lua's weak typing, anything that's not a basic type (like int or float) will be interpreted as a table, so there's no need to include all the files that depend on a given pkg, for example, if a function receives an Urho3D::Rigidbody* as a parameter on the C++ side, ToLua++ will just interpret that as a table, and then it's the lua programmer's fault if it calls it with the wrong data. Did I get this right?

- Due to my last point, I just assumed pkg includes in tolua++ are just a convenience so I can generate a C file that binds a bunch of classes right? In my case, would it be OK to just make a pkg that includes all the other pkgs so I generate a single C file to bind them all? (i.e. one C file to rule them all, and into the engine bind them... Sorry I couldn't help it  :smiley: ).

- Do I have to do anything special to deal with String, Vector and the likes? I assume Urho just maps those types to its lua equivalents. If my pkgs just reference Urho3D::String and Urho3D::Vector without doing anything else will I get that behaviour?

- Lastly, I saw some pkg files in Urho's source including header files and using "using namespace". That is done so the generated code is able to retrieve those symbols, right? In my case, all those symbols should already be in in memory when compiling the file, so there's no need for a .h include right?.

In order to share my knowledge to future readers I‚Äôll just answer my own questions with what I‚Äôve found out by trial and error:

  • If I understood correctly, each call to tolua++ generates a C file with a function that receives a pointer to the lua ‚Äúcontext‚Äù (actually called lua_state). That function adds everything that needs to be added to the Lua state. Am I right?

  • In order to actually do the binding, I should get the lua_state pointer (from the LuaScript class) and call the C generated function with it. To do so I can load the C generated function as an extern symbol into my game code, right?

All what I said above works just as I expected. I just need to get the lua_state from the LuaScript subsystem after its instantiation and call the external function generated by tolua++. That makes the C++ API available to my Lua scripts.

[quote]- Given Lua‚Äôs weak typing, anything that‚Äôs not a basic type (like int or float) will be interpreted as a table, so there‚Äôs no need to include all the files that depend on a given pkg, for example, if a function receives an Urho3D::Rigidbody* as a parameter on the C++ side, ToLua++ will just interpret that as a table, and then it‚Äôs the lua programmer‚Äôs fault if it calls it with the wrong data. Did I get this right?

  • Do I have to do anything special to deal with String, Vector and the likes? I assume Urho just maps those types to its lua equivalents. If my pkgs just reference Urho3D::String and Urho3D::Vector without doing anything else will I get that behaviour?[/quote]

Regarding all that, I‚Äôve found out most of it is true. Sadly you can pass any type to the C++ side from Lua, and you can get a lot of crashes from silly mistakes as well. But that‚Äôs what comes with such a weak typing system in combination with C++ I guess. I think URH3D_SAFE_LUA flag prevents some of those.

Even though, some types are not interpreted as tables but userdata, which is then handled with metatables.

Also, I had to do nothing to deal with Strings or Vectors, those seem to be already handled by ToLua++. I‚Äôve had to call it with the command line option ‚Äú-L ToCppHook.lua‚Äù, and I think all this is handled there.

- Lastly, I saw some pkg files in Urho‚Äôs source including header files and using ‚Äúusing namespace‚Äù. That is done so the generated code is able to retrieve those symbols, right? In my case, all those symbols should already be in in memory when compiling the file, so there‚Äôs no need for a .h include right?.

There seems to be two kinds of includes in tolua++. There are the $pfile includes, which load a package file, and generate bindings for those as well in the same binder C code. Then there‚Äôs also $#include and $using, when those are present in a pkg file, they‚Äôre copied to the generated C code.

In order for all symbols to be present in memory I‚Äôve found useful to do (in MyComponent.pkg): $#include ‚ÄúMyComponent.h‚Äù. Also for that to work you should include the same $using directrives you have in your header file (I think).

And that‚Äôs all. I still don‚Äôt know much of the lua bindings, but I‚Äôll try to make a small guide when I‚Äôm a bit more knowledgeable on the topic!

Maybe it is created in the Urho3d/CMakeLists.txt.
